msgSnippet: ... Agreed, To generalize I see three categories of those people 1) those who did not get unit testing 2) those who did and found the limitiations in JUnit
messageBody:
> Yes, this need (expensive state, sharing state, maintaining states for
> dependent test methods, etc...) is more necessary in non-unit tests,
> so I agree that it falls outside JUnit's scope. A lot of people use
> JUnit to do more than unit testing, though...
>

Agreed,

To generalize I see three categories of those people
1) those who did not "get" unit testing
2) those who did and found the limitiations in JUnit acceptable
3) those who did, found the limmitations silly but are forced to use
JUnit due to company policies or such.

I sometimes too use JUnit for my systemtesting, generally with
bumblebee. I see some advantages with those bigger tests so I'm not as
much of a unit-test fanatic as I used to be. Sometimes I'm a two on
the list but I still try to keep my setup cheap and avoid
interdependent tests. when I'm a two I tend to value isolation over
performance.

I have a feeling we understand each other now :)
